title: Dumb Quotes on Portable Word Processor
content:
I'm planning to write a novel in the month of November (NaNoWriMo if any of you are familiar with it). I have a Jornada 680e, basically a cute little word processor. My main problem, however, is that it only has dumb quotes and dumb double quotes, I'd guess you'd say? The ' and " aren't curled or anything.

As I transfer it onto my computer / work on the novel on my computer, there's obviously going to be a difference in these quotation marks. If anyone's familiar with this and knows settings to tweak / any programs, that'd be great! :-)

-- David
author: fathairyape

comments.content:
Call it text editor, a word processor does have text formatting or page layout features.  
Check out : [http://www.unmarked.com/textsoap](http://web.archive.org/web/20120913071326/http:/www.unmarked.com/textsoap "http://www.unmarked.com/textsoap")

\>As I transfer it onto my computer / work on the novel on my computer, there’s obviously going to be a difference in these quotation marks.

If you want the dumb quotes - you can turn off "smart quotes" in Word etc.,

If you want "smart quotes" I think you can "autoformat" the document to replace the straight quotes - if not I'm sure you'll find a macro to do this on the Web.

Dumb quote = Prime  
Dumb double quotes = Double prime

Thanks for the vocabulary, Solipsism. Sii--do you know what macro I'd use? Sorry, I've never really used macros! Thanks, Alessandro!

-- David

[http://www.tex-edit.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20120913071326/http:/www.tex-edit.com/ "http://www.tex-edit.com/")

Even a find & replace can do it for you in Word.

Perhaps that's even more convenient.

Thanks, Action.

Actually, what I did once I read all of these, I decided to find and replace. Originally I figured that the "s would get all screwy. It works perfectly.

Thanks to all!

-- David
